thread.title: Cardno says reject $215m Crescent bid
thread.title_full: Cardno says reject $215m Crescent bid | Business Spectator

author: Michael Roddan
title: Cardno says reject $215m Crescent bid
text:
Environmental and infrastructure services company Cardno has urged its shareholders to reject Crescent Capital Partner's proportional takeover offer after an independent expert's report labelled it neither fair nor reasonable.
Cardno directors told shareholders today to reject a $215m offer from Crescent Capital Partners' investment arm for a majority stake in the troubled company, labelling the bid opportunistic in light of the company's share price weakness amid challenging market conditions.
Sydney-based Crescent, which has a 19.62 per cent stake in the firm, had said its holding would rise to 58.9 per cent if all Cardno shareholders take up the offer, allowing it to pursue plans to halt dividend payments and rebuild shareholder value.
Crescent is offering to buy one of every two Cardno shares at $3.15 each. Cardno said its independent expert, Lonergan Edwards & Associates, valued the stock between $3.74 and $4.13 per share.
"The offer significantly undervalues Cardno, does not provide an adequate premium for control of Cardno, and is assessed as neither fair nor reasonable by the independent expert," Cardno said today.
Cardno said Crescent's intentions were not clear, whereas it was taking action to improve its recent performance. The company yesterday said it was planning to offload up to $90 million worth of assets as part of moves to get its financial house in order as it continues to fight headwinds in the oil and gas sector.
"Crescent is attempting to obtain control without having to make a full takeover for Cardno, with potentially adverse implications for non-Crescent shareholders," the company said.
Cardno yesterday said divesting businesses would bring in between $50 and $90 million to free up cash for "strategic deployment", which may include a share buyback, further acquisitions or a debt reduction. The company also found $20m of annualised savings through back office efficiencies.
Cardno has been facing numerous headwinds and has seen its share price decline from around $8 at the end of 2012 to $2.95 yesterday, after bottoming out at $2.30 in September.
“It is no accident that Crescent has launched their offer at this time,” Cardno chairman John Marlay said.
“Cardno’s share price was trading at close to five year lows reflecting, amongst other factors, the very challenging market conditions being experienced by many operators in the sector," he said.
The company has said it is likely to book a $3m to $6m hit to its pre-tax profits this year relating to the corporate costs of responding to an offer by Crescent Capital Investments.
"“The board believes that, despite the recent decline in performance, Cardno is a good business in terms of the quality of its clients, its professional services capability and the expertise of its people," Cardno said.
Cardno recently posted a loss of $145.17m in the year to June 30. The result included a post-tax non-cash impairment charge of $195.5m, associated with the reduced carrying value of Cardno's business in the US and the write down of part of the Ecuadorian business, which is for sale.
